title: madeleine mccann latest news update
story: German national Christian B, a -year-old convicted paedophile, was named as the prime suspect in the case of the three-year-old, who vanished in Portugal in .Christian B has also been linked by police to the disappearance of a six-year-old boy in Portugal in  and a five-year-old girl in Germany in .Authorities in Belgium have also linked him to the murder of missing -year-old Carola Titze, who disappeared while on holiday in De Haan in .Christian B “freaked out” in  as his staff at the kiosk-bar he ran discussed the Madeleine McCann case and then shouted: “The child is dead and that’s a good thing.”Barmaid Lenta Johlitz, , revealed: “Once he was completely freaked out when we were sitting talking with friends about the Madeleine case.“He wanted us to stop. He cried out, ‘The child is dead now and that’s a good thing’, then he said: ‘You can make a body disappear quickly. Pigs also eat human flesh’.”Christian B is currently eligible for parole having served two-thirds of his sentence for drug offences - but German legal experts say it is unlikely to go through as he is under investigation for murder.Follow our live blog below for all the latest news and updates.Heres a quick run down on the biggest stories from today.Prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters has urged Brits to come forward with any information that might help to solve the Madeleine McCann case.He told Sky News: “At the moment we also don’t have enough proof for a trial at court, but we have some evidence that the suspect has done the deed.“That’s why we need more information from people, especially places he has lived so we can target theses places especially and search there for Madeleine.”Mr Wolters added: #We need help from the people, from British tourists that might have been between  and  in Praia da Luz. Only with these calls we can solve the case of Madeleine McCann.#The hotel receptionist whose slip allegedly let Christian B know Madeleine McCann would be alone in her holiday flat will not face prosecution, a Portuguese lawyer confirmed.Christian B allegedly went to burgle the McCann flat, where Madeleine was asleep close to younger twin brother and sister Sean and Amelie.But police suspect he was overcome by an impulse to snatch the three-old.Portuguese lawyer Rui Pedro ruled out any prosecution of the receptionist.He said: “The employee in question could only face disciplinary problems.“And eventhere was intent, any crime they may have committed would now be spent.”The father of a Brit who vanished in ­Germany said he fears Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B also abducted his daughter.Trainee nurse Louise Kerton, , vanished nearly  years ago visiting her boyfriend’s family.Dad Phil, , of New Ash Green, Kent, said: “One day I feel it will be solved.”Anguished Phil Kerton pleaded with police to probe his daughters disappearance — saying evil Christian B targeted victims of all ages.Louise, , went missing in Germany in  while the Madeleine McCann murder suspect was flitting between Portugal and his German homeland.Christian B has now been linked with cases ranging from a missing girl of five to the killing of a prostitute. Phil, , told The Sun: “Christian seems to have gone after all ages, despite preferring the very young.#I would urge police to make sure his whereabouts and his activities at the time of Louise’s disappearance are properly investigated.”A prosecutor in the Madeleine McCann case has said he has #evidence# that Madeleine is dead but does not have enough to charge suspect Christian B.Hans Christian Wolters is urging British tourists and expats to help identy the suspect’s ious homes so police can launch new searches for her body.Mr Wolters told Sky News this evening that the prosecutors were missing the #hard evidence# needed for the suspect to go on trial.He said: #All indications we have got that I cant tell you points in the direction that Madeleine is dead.#The hard evidence we don’t have, we don’t have the crucial evidence of Madeline McCann’s body.#We expect that she is dead, but we don’t have enough evidence that we can get a warrant for our suspect in Germany for the murder of Madeleine McCann.#" src"https:www.thesun news uknews  german-prosecutor-evidence-maddie-dead-suspect-christian-b embed # title: buy tesla autopilot dont use it
story: The weather was good and everything was normal . . . except for the truck on its side in the outside lane.We, the viewers, could see it. All the other drivers on the motorway could see it too. But the Tesla, bombing along at around mph, with its self-drive autopilot system engaged, did NOT see it.It even went straight past the driver of the overturned truck who was at the side of the road, a good distance from the crash site, frantically warning oncoming motorists to slow down. And then came the impact.Luckily, no one was hurt. But the accident does serve as a useful reminder about technology. It can make le fun and it can make le convenient. But we’ve not yet reached a point where we can rely on it to behave itself. Take the wi in your house.The box sits in a cupboard, I should imagine, where there’s no wind or rain or weather of any kind. It is never bashed or dropped. And yet somehow, once a fortnight, it will suddenly stop working. There is no reason for this.In my London flat, the windows also serve as radiators. They are designed to come on in October and go off again in April.But every year, they get it the wrong way round and no one is able to stop them doing this, boiling me in the summer and sitting there in the winter while I slowly die of hypothermia.My laptop is no better. The last one became critically ill recently, so before it died completely, all of its information was transferred on to the model I’m using now.And that, about once a day, decides to freeze. Control-Alt-Delete  Forget it. It becomes as receptive as a brick. We have all experienced these things. And we have to believe the owner of that Tesla in Taiwan has as well.Yet he engaged the car’s self-drive system and sat back, assuming it would be able to see a crashed van directly ahead. Had he not researched the car at all  I know Tesla says its autonomous system is nine times safer than a human. But a quick Google search would suggest that sometimes, like all technology, it isn’t safe at all.I actually quite like Tesla’s current range of cars. I think they are interesting and fun and I can see why, in lockdown, the Model  was the best-selling car in Britain. But I have a word of warning for anyone tempted to buy one and engage its autopilot: Don’t.Think of it as the tool you get on a Swiss Army kne that can be used for getting stones out of a horse’s hoof. It’s a talking point . . . but you’d never actually use it.IT has been the biggest police manhunt in history. But now, after a multimillion-pound, -year search across  countries, there appears to be a genuine breakthrough in the search for Madeleine McCann.That’s great. But what staggers me is that the new chief suspect Christian B was living just a few miles from the Portuguese resort where she was last seen. His phone puts him in the resort itself on the night of the abduction.He was even interviewed by Plod back in . And it’s not like he was a model citizen. Described as a burglar and a drug dealer, it’s known he was also a paedophile. He’s even doing time in Germany right now for child sex offences. And yet somehow he was never arrested.It makes me wonder. Will they find Lord Lucan living next door to the house from which he fled in  And will it turn out that “Mr Herring” who rides around Fulham every day on a horse called Shiregar is actually the mysterious Mr Kipper who is said to have abducted Suzy Lamplugh back in  THE Hungarian justice minister Judit Varga responded angrily this week to claims her country had become a dictatorship.I’m not sure what she said, though. Because apart from the fact she speaks four languages and is a lawyer, she is . . . well, let’s put it this way. She does to me what our Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, does for the girls.“I don’t care what you’re saying just so long as you keep on saying it.”At a rough guess, I’d say  per cent of everything on the internet is wrong.WHEN London was brought to its knees by a plague in the th century, a young man called Isaac Newton fled to the countryside and while in quarantine, came up with a cure.Recently unearthed papers show how he figured out the Black Death could be beaten with a medicine made from a powdered toad and some of its vomit.After it turned out this didn’t work, he went for a sit down in an orchard, where he saw an apple fall from a tree . . .THE the last-ever .-litre Bentley V rolled off the production line this week. Now, I know with race riots and coronavirus and the economy, this doesn’t sound like a big deal. But this engine was first used in , so it’s older than me. No other engine has been made for such a long time.In the beginning, it was used in the Bentley S – a car my grandfather drove – and produced hp. Today, the same basic engine in a Mulsanne produces hp. And yet emissions have come down by a scarcely believable  per cent.In the Fties, it was the last word in silent power. And that holds true today. It’s a gentleman giant of a thing and we shall not see its like again.Sure, the motor in a modern electric car is very quiet and powerful too. But it’s the same sort of thing you get in a Magimix. Whereas Bentley’s old V  The same sort of thing you got in a Spitfire.SO, to be clear,you go to Parliament Square in a group of about ,, the police will take a knee as a mark of respect. If, however, you go to the pub with a few mates for a couple of pints, you and the man who served you will be arrested.In other news, you can go to Spain for your summer holiday but you can’t come back. Or maybe you can’t go at all. Or maybe you can . . . but onlyyou have one other travelling companion and you have a barbecue first.It’s no wonder we fear the Covid death rate will inch back up. None of us has the first clue what’s allowed any more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says sunak help motor industry
story: But now he urgently needs to turbo-charge business as the economy teeters on the edge of a catastrophic nosee.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Chancellor is drawing up a package of measures. A top priority must be a leline to the ailing car industry.This bedrock of engineering is worth £billion a year to the nation’s finances.But its collapse has already cost the economy £billion this year, putting , jobs at risk.A dismal  new cars have been built since the start of the pandemic and there is also uncertainty about Nissan’s Sunderland plant.So a revival of the car scrappage scheme is a good place to start. But it must not only apply to electric cars.Costly e-cars are out of the reach of most pockets, and charging points are thin on the ground.Rishi should make sure there is money off any new motor.Evenonly for a short time, it would give manufacturers the bump start they need.The Chancellor has a massive to-do list.But the economy won’t get out of first gearBritain doesn’t get motoring.RESTRICTIVE Sunday trading laws should be abolished.So it is encouraging to hear that Downing Street is planning to suspend them to allow bigger stores to stay open longer. The Sun on Sunday has long argued the laws are past their sell-by date but with all churches closed in the present crisis it is even more ludicrous.Many front-line heroes such as nurses can only do their weekly shop on Sundays when queues can stretch round the block.And in this economic crisis big stores are losing much needed trade.Predictably, Labour and the unions have opposed the plan.Why don’t they think about the public for a change ONE of the astonishing things to come out of the Madeleine McCann story is the fact that in Germany a convicted criminal’s identity must remain secret.In crucial appeals for information, German police can only refer to the paedophile and convicted rapist as “Christian B”.In Britain the fact of an arrest is now considered private too. title: joanne lees girlfriend peter falconio
story: What do we know about the British woman who survived an ambush by a stranger and narrowly escaped with her le Joanne Lees is a British woman who was the girlfriend of murder victim Peter Falconio.Originally from Yorkshire, she became the centre of a world-famous  murder investigation when she was found in the Australian outback claiming to have been abducted by a drter.She said she had been kidnapped, drugged, and raped by a man but soon became a prime suspect in her boyfriends murder after claims she appeared emotionless after the incident.But it was later revealed she had taken the sedative Valium to help her handle her horror ordeal.Police tapes from the investigation revealed that police at first believed she could have been involved.It wasnt until four years later that drug runner Bradley Murdoch was locked up for the crime.Lees and Falconio were both  when they were travelling in a VW Kombi van towards Darwin.The pair were flagged down by Murdoch who told them he had a problem with his exhaust.Lees managed to escape after Falconio was shot in the head. She hid in bushes for five hours, before running into the road to wave down a passing truck.She later said: It was either run, or be raped and killed.Falconios body has never been found.Lees is said to be living in a two-bedroom terrace house in her hometown of Huddersfield.She says she lives an isolated le as a social worker at the Directorate for Children and Young People for Kirklees Council.She has had ious jobs – including working at a travel agency and supporting the disabled after ing to college to study sociology.The -year-old has never married or had children following the tragic death of her boyfriend.In , she flew her back to Australia to where her boyfriend was shot in the hopes of finding his body and bringing him home to lay to rest.During the search, she discovered that she had a mirror-image sister called Jess. Jess is the daughter of her estranged Australian dad.In , Lees said she wanted to apply to become an Australian citizen.In one of the most detailed re-investigations ever mounted, a Channel  documentary series, Murder In The Outback, revisits this notorious case.Beginning on Sunday, June , and running over four consecutive nights, it follows the campaign of former lawyer Andrew Fraser to get Murdoch’s conviction overturned.It features previously unseen footage of Joanne being confronted by detectives over seeming inconsistencies in her version of the attack and raises a number of fascinating unanswered questions about a case which continues to haunt many Australians.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew report authorities
story: Ministers and officials have a duty to protect the Monarchy.Butthey refuse to hand the Prince over to the US authorities for questioning, it will look as though they are hampering an important criminal investigation and denying justice for Epstein’s many victims.Which is why Prince Andrew must report to the authorities and give the fullest, frankest statement he can muster.We know he’d rather bury his head in the sand.But the longer he stays silent, the worse the situation will get.Angry American investigators are fed up with his lack of cooperation already and have no plans to let him off the hook.Though the Prince has issued emphatic denials of wrongdoing, the very fact we have got to the point where the US is having to make back-channel requests to the Home Office in a criminal case shows just how badly the Queen’s favourite son has played this.Let’s hope he finds the guts to face up to his responsibilities — and fast.WHEN the inevitable inquiry is held into Britain’s handling of the Coronavirus pandemic, we hope Public Health England and SAGE are brought to the dock first.We know that politicians are the ultimate decision makers, so the finger of blame can’t be pointed solely at scientists.But from where we’re standing it looks like these territorial and well-funded quangos have rather a lot to answer for.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment, was against German-style mass testing and dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators.And now a top SAGE scientist has done a whopping U-turn on lockdown.John Edmunds, who claimed in mid March that herd immunity was the solution, said yesterday that he wishes Britain had shut up earlier.The Prime Minister must show leadership and reform these crumbling institutions before the public loses trust.THE hardline EU states blocking Michel Barnier from making compromises must get a grip before it’s too late.With Boris Johnson and his Vote Leave gang at the heart of government, Britain will happily walk away from talksthey don’t prove fruitful.And it will be EU leaders — already dealing with the fallout from lockdown — facing the music of a no deal Brexit at the ballot box.The UK is asking for a fair deal from the EU — hardly dferent to that which has been agreed by Canada or Japan.It’s time stubborn European politicians swallowed their pride. Our journalists strive title: trevor kavanagh boris public health bureaucrats
story: Boris Johnson is ready to reopen the pubs, restaurants and hairdressers that make ordinary le worth living by the end of this month or early July.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe plans a Save Our Summer campaign to salvage a crippled travel and leisure industry worth more than £billion — and the .million jobs that go with it.Months of self-isolation, closed shops and shuttered town centres may be nearly over.The PM is responding to dismay within his own ranks over the shambolic quarantine on air travellers, compulsory face masks and the absurd two-metre distancing rule.His focus sharpened last week when told about the likely jobs meltdown.“Christ!” he responded, and ordered a swt shake-up to the timetable for le to begin again.The PM is personally in tune with those who want rules relaxed.But he has been hemmed in by the same bumbling public-health bureaucrats who landed us with the worst Covid death toll in Europe and put the skids under the British economy.They include “Bonking Boffin” Professor Neil Ferguson, who triggered panic with alarmist predictions of , Covid corpses.But the key culprits are Public Health England, the quango whose sole responsibility is keeping us safe.Instead, they reacted like rabbits paralysed in the head-lights when the coronavirus burst out of Wuhan.Boris won’t put it like that when he addresses the nation with his plan of attack in the next week or two.But despite stern opposition from some scientic experts, he has decided the battle against the virus must be fought alongside, not after, the fight to save the health, wealth and prosperity of the nation.Track-and-trace plans will proceed at top speed, along with the search for a vaccine.The NHS will not drop its guard.But the PM is acutely aware of alarm among Tories over government floundering.“It goes from bad to worse,” said one loyalist minister. “We are looking confused. “The two-week quarantine rule is bonkers and so is the rule on face masks. “We may be popular in the polls, but governments are meant to lead public opinion, not follow.”Senior ministers, led by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, warn that each day lost before reopening Britain for business marks another swathe of jobs gone — some for ever.Mass unemployment, unseen since the Great Depression in the s, would devastate the Red Wall voters in the North and Midlands who put Boris into power.So the resumption of normal le has been brought forward by weeks.First to go will be the two-metre rule — already abandoned in reality on beaches, in parks and on Whitehall, where Black Lives Matter protesters hug each other.Strict social-distancing measures make bus and Tube travel virtually impossible. Boris wants distancing cut to one metre, giving the all-clear for pubs and restaurants to reopen and start rehiring the millions laid off since lockdown.Rishi Sunak is counting on this to trim Treasury job-support measures costing the economy a dizzying £billion.It will kickstart a new-normal summer, with open-air weddings, beer-garden service and marquees to protect punters from the rain.Summer holidays are back on track after being stymied for weeks.Airlines will bypass quarantine with air corridors to approved holiday destinations such as Italy, France, Greece and Turkey.These measures are not risk-free. Scientists point to a possible surge in Covid cases in the North.But equally reputable experts insist there is little chance of a second wave.The risk of the NHS failing to cope has now passed.Meanwhile, lockdown has brought its own death toll. Countless lives have certainly been lost from failure to diagnose and treat cancers and heart diseases.The price in lost schooling and crippled le chances will be paid for decades to come.Lting lockdown is a tough decision for any prime minister.But, as Boris knows better than most, to lead is to choose. title: treasure hunt forrest fenn rocky mountains chest found
story: Forrest Fenn, the man who created the treasure hunt, revealed on Sunday that a fortune seeker has finally uncovered the chest in the Rocky Mountains.The -year-old, an eccentric art dealer, hid the chest ten years ago and included clues to its whereabouts in a poem included his  autobiography the The Thrill of the Chase.Thousands of people have searched for the hidden loot - and at least five people have died while trying to find it.Mr Fenn confirmed in a statement on his website that the treasure chest had been discovered somewhere in the wilderness.He did not confirm the name of the lucky treasure hunter, or the chests exact location.The adventurer had sent Mr Fenn a photograph revealing his discovery but does not want his name released.Mr Fenn, who ran an art gallery in Santa Fe for  years, said: It was under a canopy of stars in the lush, forested vegetation of the Rocky Mountains and had not moved from the spot where I hid it more than  years ago.I do not know the person who found it, but the poem in my book led him to the precise spot.The chest was located somewhere in the wilderness in Montana, Wymoing, Colorado or New Mexico.It was bronze and packed with gold coins, gold nuggets, ancient Chinese jade carvings, and antique jewelry with emeralds and rubies.The chest itself weighed lbs, while its valuable contents weighed  another lbs.Mr Fenn hid the chest because he wanted to start a good old fashioned treasure hunt that would encourage people to get outside into nature and to give people hope.Internet forums and YouTube channels - such as the one run by treasure hunter Toby Younis - have sprung up dedicated to Fenn fortune as the people turned Indiana Jones to solve the mystery.Mr Fenn said: I congratulate the thousands of people who participated in the search and hope they will continue to be drawn by the promise of other discoveries.Asked how he felt about the treasure being found, Fenn said: I don’t know, I feel halfway kind of glad, halfway kind of sad because the chase is over.He wrote the poem in his autobiography that included key cryptic hints about the treasures location.It made reference to warm waters halt, the blaze and canyon down - along with other clues that had treasure hunters racking their brains.He has also given a few hints over the years, saying it was more than eight miles north of Santa Fe and was above an elevation of , feet.Mr Fenn said he delivered the chest to its secret location in two separate trips.The most recent death to hit the search was in March, when Michael Sexson, , was found dead in the wilderness.Sexson, , from Deer Park, had died by the time rescuers tracked them down, while his fellow adventurer was airlted to safety and survived.Randy Bilyeu went missing in January, , and was found dead seven months later along the Rio Grande.Bilyeu, , from Colorado, had set out on a raft and his ex-we has said she belives that Fenns treasure is actually an elaborate hoax.Jeff Murphy was found dead in June, , after falling ft down a steep slope in the Yellowstone National Park.Murphys we told authorities he was looking for the treasure when she reported him missing.Pastor Paris Wallace told his family he was searching for the treasures when he went missing in June,  as he failed to show for a family gathering.His body was found washed up along the Rio Grande after his car was found near the Taos Junction Bridge.Eric Ashby was found dead in July, , after he moved to Colorado to look for the treasure a year prior.He was last seen a month before his body was found, and it is believed his raft overturned as his remains were found in the Arkansas River.Speaking to the DailyMail in  about why he started the treasure hunt, Mr Fenn said: I had several motives.First of all, we were going into a recession – lots of people losing their jobs. I wanted to give some people hope.Despair was written all over the newspaper headlines.And secondly, we’re an overweight society – I think not only in this country, but the world.He added: So I wanted to get the kids away from their electronic gadgets … and out into the sunshine, out into the mountains, hiking, fishing, picnicking – and anything but the couch.Get out of the game room.Controversy has also dogged the search as numerous people have ended up in legal trouble.Treasure hunters have landed in hot water for digging holes in state land or having to be rescued by the authorities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beach bar closed greek mykonos party
story: Tourists flocked to the Greek party island Mykonos and flouted social distancing at the huge event in Chora as the country lted its travel ban.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesOwners of the Alemagou bar on Ftelia Beach have been fined , eurosfor disobeying safety regulations and have seen the venue ordered to shut down for two months.Pictures and video from the party show throngs of people all enjoying themselves without a single care for the threat of coronavirus.Greek bars are supposed to have one square metre of space around each customer, and tourists have been advised to wear masks while out and about. Many European nations are easing out of their lockdowns - but experts have warned of the ongoing risk of a devastating second wave.Greece has recorded , coronavirus cases, and  deaths.Secretary general for trade,Panagiotis Stampoulidis, slammed the bar for giving the Greece an unacceptable image amid the pandemic.Mr Stampoulidis said: The goal is to limit Covid-. There is a network of institutional sanctions that are very strict. It is a pity for both the employees and themselves to be locked out because they did not ensure the observance of the measures.Tourism ministers are hopeful to kick start the holiday industry to help the economy, and from June  will be allowing international visitors to .Brits were initially left off the list, but Greece has since confirmed people from the UK will be welcome subject to coronavirus tests at airports. Bars, nightclubs and internet cafes have been given the okay to reopen as Greece eases its lockdown - but they have to stick to strict guidelines.Hospitality businesses will be operate outside as much as they can as part of the rules laid out by the government for the summer season.Mr Stampoulidis said: We have opened on terms, with specic commitments. They are very simple rules. The beach bars should not open the bar and the crowd should be prevented, no parties should be created.For each area of ​​space, there is a ratio of square meters per customer .We want everyone to understand that these rules will be enforced.Greeces tourism minister Haris Theoharis has said he doesnt think many Brits will be heading to the islands this summer due to y coronavirus checks. Excluding a handful of airports - including London Southend, Bristol and Edinburgh - holidaymakers will face a testing and quarantine arrangement when arriving in Greece until the UKs coronavirus situation improves, he confirmed.Tourists will be forced to stay in a designated hotel for a few days while awaiting the result.Negative tests will result in a seven day self-isolation, while a positive test results in a -day quarantine which is supervised.Mr Theoharis said: It does mean that there is an inconvenience in the first few days.Thats why this is not going to be for the masses. It has to mean you have more time.While Greece is welcoming Brits, the UK government is yet to lower the lockdown in regards to travelling abroad with all non-essential travel still advised against.And from today Brits will need to quarantine for two weeks when ing to the UK .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: passengers arriving uk public transport no checks new rules
story: From today anyone entering Britain by plane, train or ferry must self-isolate for two weeks to stop the spread of coronavirus and prevent a second wave.Those that flout the new laws face fines of up to £, and could even face jail time.But travellers landing at Heathrow Airport today said no real checks were in place and described the system as a “shambles”.On arrival, people must now fill out forms detailing where they will be staying for the two-week period.But passengers claim no specic checks were made as they entered Britain on day one of the new rules. Pictures from Heathrow today show passengers sauntering through passport control and straight to the Tube.One man arriving into the UK from Switzerland while “feeling unwell” claimed he was NOT told to isolate after landing.The passenger, who was wearing a face mask, told ITV that he was “going on the subway” after being asked how he was getting to his destination.Reporter Martin Stew asked: “Nobody told you that you have to stay in one place for two weeks ”The man replied: “No.”The journalist continued: “And you could have a fine of maybe £,you don’t stay in one place. It’s quite bad isn’t it  If nobody has told you it’s a problem.”The passenger laughed and responded: “Yeah. I still have other issues right now so I wanted to go to the hospital.”One man told MailOnline he was headed straight for work.He said: “If Boris wants us to stay off public transport then he should arrange taxis for us all. Ive got to get to work.”And a woman arriving from Washington said: “I could have been lying the whole time.“I completed the online form before I left and when I arrived at Heathrow the immigration official asked me to repeat the address where I said I would be quarantining.“After that he just let me pass and didnt check at allwhat I had put down is true.”Another man on Twitter said his friend arrived at Heathrow “coughing everywhere” but was simply waved through. A passenger from Tel Aviv told the Evening Standard it was “chaos” as his plane landed at Heathrow.He said: “I had no idea of the quarantine. When I arrived there were long queues.”And Ali Gurlek, from London, who landed at Stansted Airport from Eindhoven in the Netherlands, said: “We didn’t know we had to fill in the form so had to do it when we arrived. “There were queues. I agree with the quarantine but this is a shambles.”A leaked Home Office document also revealed there is no method for Border Force to ensure details on entry forms are genuine.Under the new laws, ing UK residents can quarantine at home.Those without accommodation will be provided somewhere to stay by the government.The only reasons people are allowed to leave quarantine are for urgent medical attention, support from social services, food and medicinethey cannot be delivered, a funeral of a close relative, or an emergency.Police will be conducting checks to ensure people are self-isolating - and anyone flouting the rules faces a fine of up to £, and even jail.It means holidays abroad are unlikely for most people this summer.The new restrictions are in place alongside a non-essential travel ban which has seen thousands of Brits have their trips cancelled.Countries have closed their borders and airlines grounded their fleet as people are warned not to travel.But Ryanair boss Michael O’Leary claims thousands of Brit families are planning to jet off on holiday anyway.He said Ryanair has planes ready to head out to Portugal, Spain and Italy next month.He told Radio ’s Today programme: “Ryanairs taking about , daily fights from July  to destinations all over Europe, from every airport in the UK.“We are seeing thousands of British families booking their two-week holiday, because they themselves expect they wont be affected by the quarantine when theyhome.“I think the outbound holiday season will be fine - weve seen British families over the last two weeks book holidays abroad in Portugal, Spain, etc in their thousands.”Passengers arriving from the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man are exempt from the -day quarantine.And holidaymakers could use this loophole to dodge self-isolation.British travellers could come home via Dublin - being dubbed the Dublin dodge - making them exempt. It would see them avoid Irelands coronavirus quarantine rules which do not apply to people with onward journeys to the UK.Several other groups, including freight and healthcare workers, are also on the list that do not have to self-isolate.The measures will be reviewed by the government every three weeks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum coronavirus sepsis premature baby scotland
story: Mhairi Mornin, , was rushed to the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Paisley, Scotland, when she was  weeks pregnant after suffering several complications.Her baby Demi weighed just lb oz when she was born by emergency caesarean at .am on May .Shortly after, Mhairi, from Renfrewshire, started showing symptoms of coronavirus.Hours after testing positive for Covid-, Mhairi started experiencing pain in her abdomen and doctors found out it was due to a ruptured gallbladder.Her condition was rapidly deteriorating, so Mhairi was taken to the ICU unit at the hospital, where she was also diagnosed with sepsis.Because Demi was born so early and Mhairi’s health continued to cause concern, doctors told the mum she could not see her new baby.The mum-of-four said: Id only seen Demi for a few seconds before she was rushed off to the special baby unit.I lay in bed crying, wonderingit was the first and last time Id see her.Mhairis condition kept getting worse and she was worried not only for herself and her newborn, but also for other mums and babies in the unit.A team was sent to operate, but because the woman was so ill, doctors felt they could not remove the gallbladder and had to rely on surgical drains instead.After the emergency surgery, Mhairi kept feeling weaker and sicker - a situation made even worse by the fact she could not see any member of her family because of the lockdown.It was then that doctors told Mhairi she had sepsis, the Sunday Post reports.Fearing for her le, the loving mum called her eldest son William, , telling him to always remember how much she loved him and begging him to stick together with his brothers and sisters.She said: I was afraidI closed my eyes I’d never wake up again.The only thing that kept me fighting was the thought of my family growing up without me.I knew I had to find the strength from somewhere to keep going for them.As Mhairi battled both sepsis and Covid-, her husband Stephen, , had to self-quarantine.He said: The thought of ­losing Mhairi was driving me out of my mind, but I couldn’t even comfort her, the kids, or touch the baby.There were several days when it seemed my whole world was collapsing in front of my eyes.At the hospital, nurses regularly showed Mhairi photographs and videos of baby Demi.The young mum slowly started recovering and was eventually discharged from hospital  days ago.She will require surgery to remove her gallbladder once she is well enough, according to the Daily Record.Baby Demi is still in the special baby unit, but there are plans to get her out of hospital in two weeksshe continues to grow well and her coronavirus tests are clear.Mhairi can now see Demi twice a day, with the use of PPE, while her brothers and sisters can still only see her through pictures.

title: pubs demand date re open june
story: Industry leaders said yesterday at least three weeks’ notice is needed in order to train staff on the new social distancing rules.And brewers need at least three weeks to deliver draught beer.Hopes were raised yesterday after reports suggested the UK’s , pub gardens could reopen as early as June  — less than a fortnight away.But it would mean many would be without a full range of draught ales as breweries ramp up production.The Sun revealed last week how Britain’s leading breweries are aiming to produce  million pints for when the Government finally gives the green light for pubs to reopen.Downing Street cast fresh doubt on the reopening date after insisting the target remains July  at the earliest. The PM’s spokesman said: “We do want to be able to reopen pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes as soon as possible, but it must be safe to do so.“We’re working to develop a safe way for them to reopen at the earliest opportunity through our pubs taskforce. That work is going well. The roadmap sets out our ambition is to open these from th of July.”A government source suggested some in Whitehall were trying to bounce Downing Street into announcing an earlier date because they were thirsty for a pint.It followed reports in the Financial Times that three Whitehall officials said the target date was June .The trade body representing pubs and brewers last night demanded “immediate and clear” clarication over the reopening date.The British Beer  Pub Association warned that the confusion risked deepening the crisis already facing the sector and said pub owners needed certainty in order to plan.It said the Government must stick by its commitment to reopen pubs from July  or face millions more job losses. Pubs also want the Government to reduce the two metre social distancing rule to one metre.That plan was dealt a blow yesterday as the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health warned the move would cause a second spike in coronavirus cases. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tiktok creators california havoc neighbors sway la mansion
story: The group, dubbed the “One Direction of TikTok,” moved into the million “Sway LA” mansion in Calornia in January.The New York Times on Monday identied the men living in the house as Bryce Hall,  Jaden Hossler,  Josh Richards,  Quinton Griggs,  Anthony Reeves,  Kio Cyr,  and Grfin Johnson, .Neighbours in the residential neighborhood have reported hearing loud music during late hours, hearing paintball shots — as well as chants of: “Chug! Chug! Chug!”Locals have reportedly been filing noise complaints with police in Los Angeles after growing frustrated with the disturbances, which are also said to include late-night food deliveries and sidewalks pulled high with rubbish, including a large smashed up TV.Amit Runchal, a -year-old tech investment founder, and Mindy Acevedo, a -year-old law student at the University of Calornia, Los Angeles, said they’ve struggled to work from home because of all the noise coming from the TikTok creators’ house.“In the morning we hear paintball guns. title: government defeat kids school summer target
story: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is expected to say today he accepts not all schools will be able to hit the target.Ministers aimed to have all primary pupils back by June  — giving them four weeks before the summer break. But the pledge has been “under review” amid fears that it would not be possible to meet.A senior government source said the Department for Education was expected to “wind back a bit” on getting all under-s back.They said: “Some schools don’t have enough space — we have always said we will listen to schools so we are likely to step back a bit on that. Some schools are bigger so are able to split kids up. But we understand not all will be able to do this.”Primary schools have gradually been reopened for nursery, reception and Year One and Year Six groups. Children are placed in “protective bubbles” of no more than  per class to protect them from the spread of coronavirus.But the arrangements mean headteachers have to find spare rooms or spots outside in the playground for classes. And despite opposition to reopening by teaching unions, more parents than expected are understood to be sending their children to school.Ministers believe many schools will not be able to find enough space on site to get all their pupils in new, socially distanced classrooms.Instead, heads will be allowed to decide what year groups to bring back and when. They will be encouraged to give all primary pupils a stint back in the classroom.But heads may decide to do this on a rotation basis — bringing in some year groups for a fortnight and others for the following one.Whitehall still aims to have all children back to class in September.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eastenders new tarzan speak was for the hard of thinking
story: THESE last three months, it’s seemed like only two places on Earth have avoided being trapped in lockdown.Sweden and EastEnders.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd I don’t know what state of paranoid despair the Scandinavians have been enduring but I would still take my chances pub crawling in downtown Malmo before I set foot in Walford, where the only acknowledgement of the coronavirus outbreak has been a practical one.To drag out the torture, it’s now only on twice a week. A delaying-the-inevitable tactic which meant, by the time Phil and Dennis’s tickets for the April  game between West Ham and Burnley arrived in mid May, the fixture was as dead as Dennis.A lucky escapeyou ask me.The day of reckoning, when it runs out of episodes, fast approaches, of course. For the duration of the outbreak, though, it’s been a biological miracle.Regulars have packed The Vic, mobbed the Bridge Street market and just stood around gawping and muttering, in their usual community-serving way, when Keegan’s sandwich van was trashed by the local drug dealers.The presence of a global pandemic hasn’t stopped EastEnders lecturing us about other medical issues, obviously.Since the boat party accident, in February, it’s been particularly concerned about Ben Mitchell’s deafness, which cut no ice with me for a couple of good reasons.Firstly, Ben Mitchell is a dreadful, immoral, six-headed little turd who it’s impossible to like, let alone love.Secondly, they’d forgotten he was partially deaf for most of the previous decade.There’s not an international crisis or continuity glitch in the universe that can stand in the way of EastEnders’ moral grandstanding, though, so they decided viewers should “see and hear” last week’s heist episode, with Barry Grant off Brookside, through the eyes and ears of Ben.A particularly gormless enterprise, this one, which went off like Norman Collier and Jimi Hendrix on the same bill at The Half Moon in Putney, and was all feedback and missing words.To ram home the message for the hard of thinking, the action was also accompanied by word cloud subtitles that appeared to have been written by Tarzan.“Keep mind on job.”“Cut power.”“Ben, this mistake.”“Daughter without father.”Compared with other EastEnders episodes, I enjoyed it a lot. I usually do when the show tries something a bit dferent and thought you could actually write the entire history of the show in half a dozen lines of this new Tarzan-speak.“Den hate Angie.” “Peter change head.” “Phil. Him shot.” “You not mother.” “Me am mother.” “Peter change head again.” “Get out pub.” It’d be timely as well. After  years and four months of almost constant shouting and stall-minding, EastEnders goes off air next week.Tantalisingly, The Sun’s very own Andy Halls reported, on Friday, that when it s the show will have dropped its old storylines. A dream scenario which allowed me to fantasise about EastEnders .. A happier, funnier show that’s only on twice a week, where the BBC doesn’t endlessly bask in its own right-on virtue and the majority of characters actually sound like Londoners, instead of stage-schooleditorials.But that’s not going to happen, is it So I’m just going to enjoy the silence. Tarzan like.TIPPING Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in the Midlands shares its name with a meeting between two sporting rivals ”Bill: “Birmingham.”Celebrity Mastermind, John Humphrys: “In an th century poem, what season of the year did Keats describe as ‘a season of mists and mellow fruitfulness’ ”Monty Panesar: “Oliver Twist.”Ben Shephard: “The Anglo-Dutch wars were fought primarily between England and which modern-day country ”Amy: “Denmark.”.THE Last Leg, Desiree Burch on the George Floyd fallout: “Follow black artists and thinkers on social media, people who have good resources, information, opinions and insights. Right now I have two shows you could watch — Desiree’s Coming Early and Tar Baby.”Or you could watch Too Hot To Handle, where Netflix films young people having sex while artist thinker Desiree offers her “insights and opinions”.But she’s clearly too modest to mention her role on that one.THIS week’s winner is Tory MP Andrew Bridgen and Harry Enfield’s Tim Nice But Dim. Sent in by RJ.FIRST job for the Beeb’s new Director General, Tim Davie  Find out how Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer ended up on primetime, Saturday night, BBC. Seriously, how  It’s a late-night ITV show, with no one to bleep out the swearing, but with BBC levels of over-manning.The star, obviously, was Peter Crouch, who’s actually funnier than  per cent of TV comedians and more likable than all of them, but not yet ready to front his own show. So they added Maya Jama, who looked sensational in her Status Quo Blue For You-era denims, the compulsory Horne Section and Chris Ramsey, who was hiding behind a fence at the start. And should’ve stayed there. All deserve our sympathy. SOS was meant to be a Euro  spin-off and when the tournament vanished so did the show’s point. Camera angles also seem to have gone to hell, but that’s maybe an act of socially distanced mercy given what’s happening front and centre.Saturday’s content included: A teabag- flipping contest between Mo Farah and Ellie Simmonds, parachuting with Jermaine Jenas, which was straight off the Alan Partridge script and foul-mouthed football “bantz” from Rio Ferdinand, who said his career was ended by Peter Crouch, so may have been playing keepy-uppy to the Match Of The Day theme tune as some sort of twisted payback.The really alarming thing, though, is the series lasts eight weeks.Save Our Summer  At this rate, there’ll be a dark cloud hanging over autumn as well.For the record, it was the BBC News.SPRINGWATCH’s Steve Backshall wearing a “No planet B” T-shirt like he’s a -year-old student, rather than a -year-old BBC presenter who won’t shut up about his three kids. Bafta giving nominations to The Greatest Dancer and The Ranganation but not a Best Drama nod to Line Of Duty.This Morning’s Phillip Schofield losing his very short temper with John Torode over yoghurt dressing. Anyone who says “chowing down” instead of eating. And the clearly smitten GMB host Susanna Reid making an involuntary groping gesturewith her left hand, just after she says the name Keir Starmer. Easy tiger.PETER Crouch: “It wasn’t all about improving, it was also about getting better.”Ian Wright: “The one thing about Gerrard was his professionalism and the fact he was so versatile.”Paul Merson: “It was definitely half an open goal.”                                 SKY Documentaries’ McMillion, the best show on TV.Ralph’s wedding on The A Word. ITV’s th birthday tribute to the great Bradley Walsh.The GMB spat between Piers Morgan and Donald Trump’s lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, which had everything except the obvious reprimand: “Rudy. Stop your messin’ around.”And Channel ’s Murder In The Outback, where disgraced Australian lawyer Andrew Fraser proves, beyond much forensic doubt, Bradley Murdoch did indeed kill Peter Falconio.The only slight glitch being, he’s trying to prove the exact opposite.Watch it, Channel , tonight and tomorrow, pm. The self-delusion becomes hypnotic. A Gillian Burke on Springwatch B Connell Waldron on Normal People C Comedian Tom Allen on nearly everything MOST surprising thing about Britain’s Best Parent  Anita Rani isn’t the most annoying person on this Channel  show.In fact, she’s not even close to a medal position thanks to the other five – two couples and a single mum – who must champion their own style of parenting, whether  it’s “pushy” or “vegan” or mollycoddling or just sort of lying around in bed all day treating their offspring as the hired help.Like the rest of us, Channel  silently understands, of course, listening to strangers talk about their small children is no more engaging or enlightening than listening to a ­scientologist talk about L. Ron Hubbard, so they’ve included a few eccentrics to liven  up the process.On the one hand there’s martial arts enthusiast Robin, who explains: “Our parenting style is influenced by eastern philosophy. Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism,” ventriloquism, egotism, Roxette’s fourth album Tourism.On the other there’s gender fluid feminist nut Joana, who is attempting to bring up five-year-old son Willow as “a free spirit”, by banning the word “boy”, refusing to buy him “militaristic toys” and plastering her house in idiotic Socialist Worker propaganda.Hopefully, little Willow will be a stalwart of his local golf club and TA unit  in about  years’ time.But that’s no real saving grace for the show, nor a reason to watch any part of Britain’s Best Parent, apart from the final vote where, every week, the studio audience has to choose between those “free spirits” who let the kids rule the roost and those couples, like David and Nicky, who run their house more like an SAS boot camp.And every week, I’m happy to report, they vote for the boot camp.All hope for Britain may not be lost.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate middleton urges addicts seek help
story: Up to a quarter of UK adults are consuming more alcohol according to a poll by the charity Action on Addiction and YouGov.Nearly one in four with a history of addiction has reported a recurrence of their addictive behaviour or have recently relapsed while in recovery.The shocking statistics also show an increase in addictive behaviour from children as young as .Kate, , made a virtual visit to the Clouds House rehab centre in Wiltshire via a video call from the Cambridges’ family home, Anmer Hall in Norfolk.The Duchess said: “The worrying thing is, it is all those people who aren’t necessarily reaching out who are struggling, who perhaps don’t feel they can reach out.“Or the fact that maybe they haven’t realised that addictive behaviours have sort of established, particularlyit’s the first time - and it’s those people who aren’t necessarily being vocal about it, it’s making sure that they know they can reach out and that you are there to help and support them in this very dficult time.”Clinical lead Dr Simone Yule said: “We are seeing more alcohol issues in the community.“I think we definitely know alcohol sales have gone up exponentially and the rise in people that are now starting to seek treatment with lockdown gradually lting, I think that is going to have a big impact.”The survey by Action on Addiction revealed a quarter of UK adults are drinking more than they were before lockdown.Four per cent of those surveyed reported an increase in online gambling and  per cent, or , people, confessed to gambling problems.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids teachers tested coronavirus schools
story: Matt Hancock wants tests to be carried out at  educational settings – including  in London - before the summer holidays.The Health Secretary says the crucial data will help us better understand rates of transmission within schools.Experts will also be able to accurately estimate how many children carry the bug but have no symptoms of the disease.Nurses will carry out regular swabs on  teachers and pupils from each setting to look for infections.And medical professionals will also take a blood test at the start and end of the study in  schools, to seeparticipants have antibodies against the bug.Officials hope the findings will help open up classrooms to more children in September by revealing how to best minimise coronavirus spread.Mr Hancock said: “A critical pillar of our Covid- testing strategy is surveillance – testing samples of the population to gain a deeper understanding of the spread of Covid- - especially in those who may not have symptoms.“This study will help us better understand how common asymptomatic and mild cases of Covid- are so that we can support parents, pupils and teachers and staff, and inform our ongoing response to this new virus.”Volunteers will need both headteacher and parent permission before taking part, with nurses visiting schools to carry out checks.Some participants will also give a two blood samples to look for antibodies against the virus, which show they previously have had the bug.They will all have five weekly swabs to test whether they currently have the infection.The pilot scheme, run by Public Health England, will inform a much bigger school surveillance study in the autumn.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “We know that being in school is vital for children’s education and their wellbeing.“Last week, primary schools began to welcome back some pupils and secondary schools will begin to do the same from  June, as part of our phased and cautious approach to getting children and young people back into the classroom.“Studies like this will be invaluable as we continue moving forward with those plans, and help us assess the next steps for getting all children back into schools, nurseries and colleges with their friends and teachers.”Britain’s top child doctor welcomed the research, saying it will help reassure parents and teachers.Professor Russell Viner, President of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said: “This is a really important step. We need to clearly understand what role children and schools plan in transmission of the virus.“More data collection is crucial to reassure people that it is safe for schools to reopen and carefully monitor their impact on Covid spread.“This will tell us how rapidly we can get children back into school.”Community surveillance by the Office for National Statistics has already found the number of infected people in England has halved in two weeks.Officials say there were an estimated , new infections per week, or , a day, from April  to May .Speaking at the Downing Street briefing, Mr Hancock announced an extension of Covid testing in English care homes.He said working age adult care homes would now be included.Ministers have already sent testing kits for all residents and staff in elderly care settings by their early June target date.Mr Hancock said: “We will now make sure that we do all of this in working age care homes as well.I can announce that from today all remaining adult care homes in England will be able to order the whole care home testing service for residents and staff.This service will benefit residents and staff in over , more care homes. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Its Ruby Flamingo Frappuccino has chocolate chips, raspberry syrup and whipped cream.A large Venti cup contains . grams of added sugar and has  calories — almost the same as two McDonald’s hamburgers.The medium-sized Grande contains .g. title: secondary schools could stay shut past september matt hancock
story: The Health Secretary signalled pupils might be stuck at home for months to come, with secondary schools opening in September at the earliest”.Speaking at the Downing Street press conference yesterday, Mr Hancock said that some schools may not be able to open for the beginning of the next academic year.He said: “Our current working plan is secondary schools won’t be open until September at the earliest.“I very much hope that they can because the impact on children’s education is so signicant.”Pupils in reception, year one and year six went back into the classroom on June , and kids in year  and year  are expectedto school on Monday - although the Government has said remote learning “should remain their predominant mode of education.”The Health Secretary said yesterday: “What we have to do – not only in schools, but right across the board – is work out how we can get the other things that matter going.“Like schools, like hospitality, like retail. And get them going safely and carefully, in a way that doesn’t lead to the spread of the virus, and that is going to require ingenuity.”Ministers are refusing to guarantee a reopening date for schools in case the infection rate increases, according to The .Anne-Marie O’Leary, editor of parenting website Netmums, said parents needed more clarity on when kids would be ing to the classroom.She said: “The inability to plan is the biggest burden on parents right now. The fact they dont know what schools are going to look like in September means that parents cant plan what their work le needs to look like.She added: Keeping teens away from their friends is almost removing their leline. Andparents go back to work, as they are encouraged to, there is a mental health burden for children stuck at home on their own.It comes as the Government is set to water down its pledge to give primary school kids a month back at school.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is expected to say later today that he accepts not all schools will hit the target.The Government wanted to have all primary pupils back in the classroom by June  for four weeks of teaching before the summer break, but the pledge is now “under review”.A government source said the Department for Education was expected to “wind back a bit” on getting under-s back.They said: “Some schools don’t have enough space – we have always said we will listen to schools so we are likely to step back a bit on that.“Some schools are bigger so are able to split kinds up. But we understand not all will be able to do this.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michel barnier rejects uk trade demand terms japan
story: He threw out a UK request to help smooth the way for companies that rely on global supply chains.The move is a major blow to both British and European businesses, including car makers and food producers.It set up another row with No, which has accused the Frenchman of singling the UK out for unfair treatment.A senior EU official insisted: This is an area where we do not in any way see any margin of compromise. We do not believe that it is in the EU interest.But No hit back. A British official said: “The UK’s rules of origin proposals are appropriate and modern.“They are based on substantial dialogue with UK and EU industry on their needs, and would facilitate legitimate trade under the FTA without circumventing the payment of tarfs.“Cumulation already features in many of the EU’s FTAs, such as its agreement with Singapore.”Among those urging the Frenchman to rethink is the lobby group Chocolate, Biscuits and Confectionery of Europe.It called on him to protect the close and integrated supply chains between UK and EU food and drink producers have built over the last decades.Chocolate, sweets, and biscuits are among the EUs top food and drink exports to the UK - worth £.bn a year.No is seeking a pact with Brussels that would allow manufacturers to benefit where both sides do a trade deal with the same country.It would mean components sourced from a mutual partner wouldnt count towards limits on how much foreign material can be used in production - known as rules of origin.That is important for many companies on both sides of the Channel that assemble complex products using parts shipped in from abroad.Goods traded between the UK and EU after Brexit will attract a tarf unless the maker can prove how much of their value was produced domestically.Such a clause has been inserted into Brussels FTA with Japan, but trade experts said they are rare in dealings with the bloc.They added the UK was having to ask for an exceptional catch-all solution because of the short time-frame for the talks.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman screams waiting mcdonalds
story: The dramatic confrontation saw the woman appear to almost run over the man as he refused to let them in the long queue.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe altercation began at the Enfield restaurant in North London after the staff member refused to allow the women to join the queue due to a build up of traffic on the A on Saturday.The video shows the McDonald’s employee, wearing a face mask, standing at the start of the drive-thru lane refusing to let the black car enter the queue.The driver is repeatedly heard saying “move” however, the employee stands his ground.The driver then gets out and confronts him, shouting: “Move away from my car.” She then appears to push the employee away from her car and screams: “Oh just f*** off man it’s food! You dumb s*** you f****** p****. I hope you f***ing die!”In the back, a small child can be seen watching the bitter clash.After her tantrum the woman begins to drive towards the queue, but is blocked again by the employee.The stand-off continues, and another woman gets out of the car and appears to shove the employee out of the way.At this point the manager arrives and shouts: “I am not serving you!” As the argument continues. The professional employees stand firm and refuse to let the women join the queue.This sends the older woman into a tirade as she slaps and grabs the McDonald’s employee and shouts: “f*** you!” repeatedly. Eventually the women back off and the incident comes to an end.Clips of the abuse were uploaded to Facebook and posted publicly by Shyaan Anais Salih shortly after.Shyaan posted: “I am disgusted with what I witnessed today!This person told this McDonald’s worker that she was driving into Krispy Kreme when she was deliberately trying to enter the McDonald’s drive-thru. “The drive-thru line was closed off due to build up of traffic happening on the A, hence why her, and the cars behind werent allowed. I can’t believe the amount of verbal and physical abuse this guy experienced when he was only following the rules required of his job role.“To attempt to run over and to slap, push and punch this guy just to get in the queue for a McDonald’s is absolutely disgusting.People like this have no respect and no morals, and to top that she had a young child in the car!The abuse this staff member experienced was uncalled for! This abuse happened for over  minutes.“Can I just say that it is so important to respect everyone no matter what job role they have. Clearly these people have zero respect! For this person to say “I hope you die” and other things is actually so disgusting!”A McDonalds spokesperson said: The safety and security of our people is our absolute priority. This behaviour from any customer is completely unacceptable and we have a zero tolerance policy when it comes to anti-social behaviour of any kind. We’d like to thank our employees for handling this situation both calmly and professionally. We are aware things are taking a little longer than normal as our restaurant teams adjust to new procedures, and that things are operating a little dferently at the moment, and we’d like to thank all our other customers for their continued patience.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampaigners have launched a legal bid to force the Government to open an inquiry into failures in getting PPE to NHS staff and care workers. The crowdfunded legal challenge is being brought by the Doctors’ Association UK, Hourglass Abuse, and the Good Law Project. Their legal bid claims that thehe Department of Health’s has  legal obligation to launch an investigation into whether failures to provide adequate PPE may have caused or contributed to the deaths or serious illness from COVID- of workers in the health and social care sectors, as well as patients. They launched their legal action after government lawyers said an inquiry was unnecessary. Ministers have said setting up the investigation would distract the Department of Health and Social Careand other key bodies involved in arranging the supply of PPE or guidance about what kit should be used. The group claim that there have been at least  deaths of NHS staff and  deaths of social care workers in England. Dr Rinesh Parmar, Chair of the Doctors’ Association UKsaid: We have seen over the last few weeks that the UK has one of the highest death rates from COVID- in the world. Health and social care workers rose to the challenge, ed to the frontline from retirement and pulled out all the stops to save lives. Some had no personal protective equipment , others had inadequate, out of date perishing supplies.  Alongside caring for patients, we’ve cared for colleagues and also faced the sad and grim reality of losing colleagues, who themselves were caring for patients. Now is the time to learn key lessons to enable us to avoid future pitfalls, protect the frontline and ultimately save lives. Our calls for a public inquiry and our petition of nearly , signatures have all fallen on deaf ears as the government buries its head in the sand and steadfastly refuses to commit to the learning required to prevent further tragedies.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMatt Hancock today claimed coronavirus is in retreat across the land, despite some scientists believing it could be spreading exponentially in certain regions of the UK. The Health Secretary accepted a Public Health England model last week showed R - the number of people each carrier infects - was . in the South West and . in the North West. But he insisted the model was one of just ten on the R rate, and overall, the consensus view is that R is below one in every region of the UK.He did not give exact figures, but told the Commons it was wrong to focus only on one model.Speaking as daily deaths across the UK fell to , the lowest single day since lockdown, he added:Coronavirus is in retreat across the land. Our plan is working and these downward trends mean we can proceed with our plans. But we do so putting caution and safety first. However,  Mr Hancock warned the  daily deaths would rise again because todayaposs figure was for Sunday - which is always lower due to reporting delays. He added: “Each death brings just as much sadness as when the figure was much higher in the peak”.It comes after the UK’s Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesfound the R was .-. in the UK, and slightly higher for England at .-. That estimate was partly made through modelling by Public Health England and Cambridge University’s MRC Biostatistics Unit. That estimated the R number as being a median of . in the North West and . in the South West. The findings prompted alarm from northern leaders who warned it showed lockdown was being eased too quickly in England. Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham and Liverpool City Region mayor Steve Rotheram warned the R change as signicant. They warned yesterday: The spread of the virus ies widely within regions and even within local authority areas. To this point, however, the public have been given very little localised information. But Mr Hancock today insisted that overall, the R number was below  in each region of the UK. The Health Secretary appeared to blame the media for reporting the information, which was provided to the media in a press release from Public Health England. He said: It is important that the media reports the facts, which are thatyou take into account all these models, then R is below one according to SAGE in each region of the country.  Of course scientic models will come out with dferent results. And itaposs quite right the scientists should publish and discuss those - thataposs how science advances. But itaposs also important that the media play their part responsibly. He added: The way you get the best advice is by looking at all dferent models, rather than just one. Mr Hancock also clashed with an MP who he accused of misquoting one of the governmentaposs scientic advisors. SNP MP Neale Hanvey said growing number of experts were warning of a “signicant second wave” He added: SAGE member John Edmunds told Andrew Marr the decision not to lock down earlier had ‘cost a lot of lives’. He went on: If the government is no longer following the science provided by their own advisors, whose advice are they following  Mr Hancock said Mr Hanvey had “misquoted” one of the professors he referred to in his question and did not elaborate further. He added: “I’m afraid the honourable gentleman has misquoted Prof Edmunds and I think he should go and look at what was actually said.” Yet Prof Edmunds clearly said: We should have gone into lockdown earlier. I think it would have been hard to do it, I think the data we were dealing with in early parts of March and our situational awareness was really quite poor. And so I think it would have been very hard to pull the trigger at that point. But I wish we had, I wish we had gone into lockdown earlier. I think that has cost a lot of lives, unfortunately.” The government is preparing to allow non-essential shops to reopen from June  - along with places of worship for private prayer. People will be forced by law to wear face coverings on public transport for the first time. But Downing Street today accepted its own coronavirus aposalertapos level could still be at  - which it has been since March - when that happens. Boris Johnson ’s spokesperson has said changes to lockdown measures are “guided by the scientic and medical advice” and the separate five tests for easing lockdown.The spokesman said that while the decision on reopening is conditional it wouldnapost necessarily be accompanied by a drop to level three in the warning system.

Ms Patel, making a statement to MPs, said any large gatherings of people are currently unlawful before adding: We cannot afford to forget weaposre still in the grip of an unprecedented national health emergency that has tragically claimed more than , lives. But MPaposs clashed over the Governmentaposs response to the protesters. Labouraposs Flo Eshalomi challenged Ms Patelaposs account and said the government did not understand racial inequality. She added: Well, on that basis, it must have been a very dferent Home Secretary who as a child was frequently called a Paki in the playground, a very dferent Home Secretary who was racially abused in the streets or even advised to drop her surname and use her husbands in order to advance her career. Labouraposs Nick Thomas-Symonds told the Commons said that MPs couldnapost ignore the demands of protesters for change. He said: We cannot allow this moment of global demand for justice to pass without action and we on these benches will be at the forefront of calls for change. story: NewsCoral and Ladbrokes install sneeze screens as betting shops reopen next weekBookmakers are set to reopen their doors from June  with changes made to adhere to social distancing guidelines including sneeze screens at Coral and Ladbrokes shopsShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of BusinessJeremy Culley:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsBookies are reopening from June  as lockdown eases " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBookmaker chains Coral and Ladbrokes are installing ‘sneeze screens’ in shops as part of plans to reopen from next Monday. Shops will have extra customer signage and stylus pens for using on betting stations and gaming machines to avoid customers needing to physically touch them, said owner GVC Holdings. Staff will also be protected with iding partitions from customers when they place bets or collect winnings. GVC plans to open all , Coral and Ladbrokes shops in England from Monday June . But bookmakers need to wait for lockdown rules to change in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland before shops can reopen there. Most non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen from the same date.The two month lockdown because of coronavirus, and the suspension of live sport, has hammered the betting sector.Horse racing has restarted, albeit meetings will be held behind closed doors with strict testing and social distancing measures enforced. And the Premier League and Championship are set to resume from June  and  respectively. Punters can still sit normally and play at betting machines but the plastic screen barriers will be in place for safety. Coral says there will be small reductions in the number of customers allowed in shops, depending on the size of the branch. There will be signs on the floor to remind punters about social distancing. Betting slips still remain and the same. Customers will need to place bets earlier than ever as queues may take longer, The Sun reports. Coral is reportedly encouraging contactless payments - but they will accept cash too, while hand sanitiser will be provided to customers.Simon Clare, PR director at Ladbrokes Coral told The Sun : “We are really looking forward to seeing our customers again.“People will just need to keep a safe distance from each other.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMore than three million deaths may have been prevented by coronavirus lockdowns across Europe, research suggests. A modelling study from Imperial College London scientists, involving data from  European countries up to early May , found that lockdowns had a substantial effect in reducing transmission levels of Covid-. European countries began implementing social distancing, school closures and national lockdowns in March, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson putting the UK in lockdown on March , a date critics say was too late after a delay that cost lives. The Imperial researchers estimate that across all  countries - the UK, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland - between  and  million people were infected with Covid- up to May , representing between .% and .% of the population. Their analysis suggests . million lives were saved across the continent, including , in the UK, , in France and , in Italy. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.   In their paper, published in the Nature journal, they said the results show that major non-pharmaceutical interventions and lockdown in particular have had a large effect on reducing transmission. The paper says: Continued intervention should be considered to keep transmission of SARS-CoV- under control. By comparing the deaths predicted under a model with no interventions to the deaths predicted in an intervention model, the researchers calculated that . million deaths have been averted across the  countries due to interventions since the beginning of the epidemic.  Dr Samir Bhatt, study author from the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis, Jameel Institute , Imperial College London, said: This data suggests that without any interventions, such as lockdown and school closures, there could have been many more deaths from Covid-. The rate of transmission has declined from high levels to ones under control in all European countries we study. Our analysis also suggests far more infections in these European countries than previously estimated.  Careful consideration should now be given to the continued measures that are needed to keep SARS-CoV- transmission under control. The publication of the research comes after Health Secretary Matt Hancock insisted the Government made the right decisions at the right time with the lockdown, despite a leading scientist saying lives would have been saved had ministers acted sooner. Infectious diseases expert, Professor John Edmunds, who attends meetings of the Governmentaposs Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , told BBC Oneaposs The Andrew Marr Show on Sunday: We should have gone into lockdown earlier. I think it would have been hard to do it, I think the data that we were dealing with in the early part of March and our kind of situational awareness was really quite poor. And so I think it would have been very hard to pull the trigger at that point but I wish we had - I wish we had gone into lockdown earlier. I think that has cost a lot of lives unfortunately. Meanwhile, a second study from the University of Calornia, looking at China, South Korea, Italy, Iran, France, and the United States, estimates that interventions in those countries prevented or delayed around  million cases.
